title: 1. Walking
howToDo: Start with 20–30 minutes per day;;Split into two sessions if easily fatigued (e.g., 15 mins morning + 15 mins evening).
whenToDo: Morning and/or early evening after a light snack.
howToIncrease: If 30 mins feels easy, increase pace slightly or include 1–2 gentle inclines (if available).
whenToStop: If you feel pelvic pressure, uterine cramps, vaginal discharge, or fatigue — take a break immediately.
avoidIf: You have low-lying placenta (placenta previa), short cervix, or signs of early labour. Always confirm with your doctor.

title: 2. Pelvic Tilts (Cat-Cow Pose)
howToDo: Get on all fours on a yoga mat;;Inhale, arch your back (cow), look up;;Exhale, round your back (cat), look down toward your belly.
repsPerDay: 2 sets of 10 repetitions, twice a day.
whenToDo: Morning and late afternoon. Avoid doing it right after meals.
howToIncrease: Gradually increase reps to 15–20 per session if comfortable.
whenToStop: Stop if you feel any wrist pressure, dizziness, or abdominal discomfort.
avoidIf: You have wrist issues, high blood pressure with dizziness, or restricted movement due to twin pregnancy or polyhydramnios.

title: 3. Squats (with Support)
howToDo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart;;Hold onto the back of a chair, bed, or wall for support;;Inhale and slowly squat down, keeping knees over toes;;Exhale and return to standing.
repsPerDay: Start with 5 squats, slowly increase to 15–20 per day.
whenToDo: Once daily — preferably after warming up with a walk.
howToIncrease: Increase depth and reps gradually, and do 2 sets of 10 squats once you feel stable.
whenToStop: If you feel pelvic pain, dizziness, or knee strain.
avoidIf: You have pelvic instability (symphysis pubis dysfunction), dizziness, or low-lying placenta.

title: 4. Butterfly Pose (Baddha Konasana)
howToDo: Sit on a yoga mat or firm mattress;;Join your feet together in front of you, knees pointing outwards;;Hold your feet and gently flap your knees like butterfly wings.
whenToDo: Anytime during the day when relaxed; best after walking.
howToIncrease: Increase to 5 minutes per session as flexibility improves.
whenToStop: Stop if you feel groin pain or leg numbness.
avoidIf: You have pelvic pain or recent vaginal bleeding. Use cushions under your thighs for support if needed.

title: 5. Wall-Supported Deep Breathing
howToDo: Stand with your back gently against a wall;;Close your eyes, rest your hands on your belly;;Inhale deeply through the nose for 4 seconds;;Hold for 2 seconds;;Exhale slowly through the mouth for 6 seconds
duration: Start with 5–10 minutes daily, increase as needed.
whenToDo: After exercise, before sleep, or during anxiety spells.
howToIncrease: Add soothing music or guided breathing meditation once you’re comfortable.
whenToStop: If you feel breathless, dizzy, or your heart races.
avoidIf: No specific contraindications — safe for most women unless advised rest due to preterm labour signs.

title: 6. Pregnancy Ball Exercises (Birthing Ball Movements)

variations.name: Pelvic Circles
variations.howToDo: Sit upright on the ball with feet flat and slightly apart;;Rotate hips in gentle circles — clockwise and anticlockwise.
variations.whenToDo: After walking or when feeling stiff

variations.name: Figure 8 Movements
variations.howToDo: Same seated position. Move hips in a figure-8 shape.

variations.name: Gentle Bouncing
variations.howToDo: Sit comfortably, shoulders relaxed, and bounce lightly.
variations.whenToDo: Once or twice daily — best done in the last 1–2 weeks of pregnancy

howToIncrease: Start slow with 5–6 minutes total ball use per day. Slowly increase to 10–15 minutes as comfort allows. Always stop if there is any discomfort.
whenToStop: If you feel pelvic pain, heaviness, dizziness, or loss of balance. If contractions start prematurely or there's any fluid leakage.
avoidIf: You have pelvic instability (SPD). You're on bed rest. You have bleeding, leaking, or breech presentation (without doctor’s clearance).
proTip: Always use the ball on a non-slip floor, and preferably near a wall or bed for support. Choose the right size — 65 cm ball for average Indian height (5'3"–5'7").

title: 7. Malasana (Deep Squat or Garland Pose)
howToDo: Stand with feet slightly wider than hip-width;;Toes turned slightly outward;;Squat down slowly, keeping spine tall;;Bring palms together in front of chest in Namaste;;Elbows should press lightly against inner knees.
duration: Start with 30 seconds, twice daily. Slowly increase to 1–2 minutes per session.
proTip: Use a cushion under your heels or hold a bed/pillar if needed for balance.
howToIncrease: Begin with 2 squats per day of 30 seconds each. Gradually move to holding the pose for 1 minute twice daily. If you are already used to Indian-style squatting, increase slowly.
whenToStop: If you feel knee or ankle strain. If you feel pelvic pressure, dizziness, or vaginal heaviness. If your doctor asks you to avoid squatting for medical reasons.
avoidIf: You’ve had a previous cesarean with low-lying placenta. You’re experiencing bleeding, pelvic pain, or if the cord is around the baby’s neck. Your doctor has advised no squatting for specific conditions (e.g., high BP, IVF pregnancy).
